sections.content: First customers are hardest. No social proof, no reviews, no brand. You're asking people to trust complete unknown. But first customers don't need to come from ads or SEO—they come from your network, hustle, and direct outreach. Launch to your world first. Friends, family, colleagues, social media connections. Then leverage those initial customers to reach next wave.

sections.title: First Customer Channels
items: Personal network: Email everyone you know, post on social
Direct outreach: Email/DM ideal customers directly
Communities: Reddit, Facebook groups, Slack communities, forums
Content: Blog posts, videos solving their problems
Partnerships: Collaborate with complementary businesses
Events: Industry events, meetups, conferences
Cold calls: Old school but works for some businesses

sections.content: Do things that don't scale: Personally recruit every early customer. Hand-written emails. Custom onboarding. Over-deliver on service. This doesn't scale to 10,000 customers. But it gets you to 10. Those 10 become testimonials, case studies, referrals that get you next 100. Then you build scalable systems.

sections.title: The Founder Sales Approach
items: Personal: You're the founder, that's powerful
Story: Share why you built this, your vision
Listen: Understand their specific situation
Customize: Tailor solution to their needs
Relationship: Building partnership, not just transaction
Learn: Every conversation teaches you about market
Feedback: Ask what would make it perfect for them

sections.title: Early Customer Incentives
items: Founder's discount: Significantly lower price for early adopters
Lifetime deal: Pay once, use forever
Beta access: Exclusive early access
Influence: Their feedback shapes product
Recognition: Feature them as founding customers
Custom features: Build what they specifically need
Trade: Their testimonial/case study for discount

sections.content: The 10-100-1000 rule: First 10 customers from personal hustle. Next 100 from those 10 (referrals, testimonials, case studies). Next 1000 from scalable channels (content, ads, SEO). Don't try to jump to 1000 without doing work to get 10. Each stage teaches you what you need for next.

sections.title: Conversion Tactics
items: Free trial: Let them experience value first
Demo: Show don't tell, personalized walkthrough
Case studies: Proof others succeeded
Testimonials: Social proof from similar customers
Guarantee: Money-back guarantee removes risk
Urgency: Limited spots or limited-time pricing
Make it easy: Frictionless signup and payment

quiz.question: Where do first customers come from?
options: Personal network, hustle, and direct outreach
quiz.explanation: First customers come from personal network, hustle, and direct outreach. Launch to your world first. Ads and SEO come after proving product.

quiz.question: What's the 10-100-1000 rule?
options: First 10 from hustle, next 100 from referrals, next 1000 from scalable channels
quiz.explanation: 10-100-1000: First 10 from hustle, next 100 from those 10 (referrals), next 1000 from scalable channels. Each stage teaches what's needed for next.

sections.content: Sales is serving, not manipulating. You're helping people solve problems, not tricking them into buying. This mindset shift removes guilt and makes sales natural. If you truly believe your product helps, your ethical obligation is to sell it. Not selling means letting people suffer with problem you can solve. Sales = service.

sections.title: Sales Fundamentals
items: Listen first: Understand their problem deeply
Qualify: Are they good fit? Do they have problem you solve?
Value: Communicate value, not features
Handle objections: Address concerns honestly
Ask for sale: Explicitly ask them to buy
Follow up: Most sales happen after multiple touches
Service: Focus on helping, not closing

sections.content: The sales conversation framework: 1) Build rapport, 2) Understand their situation and problem, 3) Present solution tailored to them, 4) Handle objections, 5) Close with clear ask. Most founders skip #2—they pitch too early. Diagnose before prescribing. The more they talk, the more likely they buy.

sections.title: Key Sales Questions
items: 'What's your biggest challenge with [area]?'
'How are you currently handling this?'
'What happens if you don't solve this?'
'What would ideal solution look like?'
'What's preventing you from solving this?'
'If I could solve this for you, would that be valuable?'
Then present: 'Based on what you shared, here's how we can help...'

sections.title: Handling Objections
items: 'Too expensive': 'What's it costing you to not solve this?' (ROI focus)
'Need to think about it': 'What specifically do you need to think about?' (uncover real objection)
'Not now': 'What would need to change for it to be right time?' (timing clarity)
'Competition is cheaper': 'What makes their solution different?' (value comparison)
'Need to ask boss': 'Can we schedule call with them?' (reach decision maker)
Welcome objections: Means they're engaged and considering

sections.content: Closing techniques: Trial close ('Does this make sense so far?'), assumptive close ('Should I send contract to this email?'), direct close ('Are you ready to move forward?'), urgency close ('This rate expires Friday'). Most important: Actually ask for the sale. Many founders present but never ask.

sections.title: Follow-Up Strategy
items: Timing: Follow up within 24 hours
Persistence: 5-7 touches before most sales
Value: Each follow-up adds value, not just 'checking in'
Multiple channels: Email, phone, social media
Content: Share relevant article, case study, insight
Calendar: Set reminders, use CRM to track
Don't give up: 'No' often means 'not now'

quiz.question: What's the right sales mindset?
quiz.explanation: Sales is serving, not manipulating. Helping people solve problems. If you believe product helps, ethical obligation is to sell it. Sales = service.

quiz.question: How many touches before most sales?
quiz.explanation: 5-7 touches before most sales. Persistence matters. Each follow-up should add value, not just 'checking in.' Don't give up after one 'no.'

sections.content: Growth marketing isn't just marketing—it's systematic approach to growing business through experimentation. Traditional marketing: run campaigns, hope they work. Growth marketing: hypothesize, test, measure, optimize, repeat. It's scientific method applied to customer acquisition. Small businesses can compete with big companies by being smarter, faster, more experimental.

sections.title: Growth Channels
items: Content marketing: SEO, blog, YouTube, podcast
Social media: Organic and paid on relevant platforms
Email marketing: Newsletter, nurture sequences
Paid ads: Google, Facebook, LinkedIn ads
Partnerships: Affiliates, co-marketing, integrations
Referrals: Customer referral programs
Community: Build or participate in communities
Start: Pick 1-2 channels where your customers are

sections.content: The bullseye framework: List all possible channels. Test cheaply (spend $1000 and a week testing each). Identify top 1-2 channels with best results. Double down on winners. Most founders spread thin across channels. Winners focus deeply on 1-2 channels that work.

sections.title: Growth Experiments
items: Hypothesis: 'If we do X, then Y will happen because Z'
Metrics: What will you measure? (signups, revenue, engagement)
Test design: How will you run experiment?
Duration: Usually 1-2 weeks
Analysis: What happened? Why?
Action: Keep winner, kill loser, iterate
Velocity: Run 1-2 experiments weekly

sections.title: Key Growth Metrics
items: CAC: Customer acquisition cost per channel
LTV: Lifetime value of customer
Conversion rate: % of visitors who become customers
Activation: % who have 'aha moment'
Retention: % who stay/return
Referral rate: % who refer others
Payback period: How long to recover CAC

sections.content: The pirate metrics (AARRR): Acquisition (how do they find you?), Activation (do they have good first experience?), Retention (do they come back?), Revenue (do they pay?), Referral (do they tell others?). Optimize in order. No point optimizing referrals if you can't activate or retain customers.

sections.title: Quick Wins
items: Landing page optimization: Test headlines, CTAs, images
Email capture: Pop-up, lead magnet, exit intent
Social proof: Add testimonials, reviews, customer count
Free trial: Remove friction with trial vs. immediate payment
Onboarding: Guide to 'aha moment' quickly
Re-engagement: Email inactive users
Referrals: Ask happy customers to refer

quiz.question: What's the bullseye framework?
options: Test all channels cheaply, double down on 1-2 winners
quiz.explanation: Bullseye framework: Test all channels cheaply. Identify top 1-2 with best results. Double down on winners. Focus beats spreading thin.

quiz.question: What are the pirate metrics (AARRR)?
quiz.explanation: AARRR: Acquisition, Activation, Retention, Revenue, Referral. Optimize in this order. Framework for understanding and optimizing growth funnel.

sections.content: Acquiring customer is expensive. Keeping customer is cheap. 5x more expensive to acquire new customer than retain existing one. Plus, retained customers buy more over time. Yet most businesses obsess over acquisition, neglect retention. Leaky bucket problem: pouring in new customers while old ones leave. Fix retention first, then scale acquisition.

sections.title: Why Customers Leave
items: Poor onboarding: Never experienced value
Not using product: Didn't form habit
Expectations mismatch: Product didn't deliver promise
Better alternative: Competitor offered more value
Price: Can't afford or doesn't justify cost
Change in needs: Problem solved or changed
Bad experience: Customer service issue

sections.content: The retention equation: Retention = (Getting value) - (Friction + Alternatives). Increase value, decrease friction and alternatives. Value: does product deliver on promise? Friction: how hard is it to use? Alternatives: why should they choose you? Address all three.

sections.title: Improving Retention
items: Onboarding: Guide to quick win within first session
Activation: Get them to 'aha moment' fast
Habit formation: Encourage regular usage through triggers
Value reminders: Show impact and progress
Engagement: Regular communication with value
Support: Proactive help before they struggle
Feedback: Ask for input, implement suggestions

sections.title: The 'Aha Moment'
items: Definition: Moment customer experiences core value
Facebook: Adding 7 friends in 10 days (connections = value)
Slack: Team sending 2,000 messages (communication flowing)
Your business: What action correlates with retention?
Identify: Analyze retained vs. churned customers
Optimize: Get new users to aha moment fast
Goal: Aha moment in first session if possible

sections.content: Measuring satisfaction: NPS (Net Promoter Score) asks 'How likely would you recommend us?' on 0-10 scale. 9-10 = Promoters. 7-8 = Passives. 0-6 = Detractors. NPS = % Promoters - % Detractors. Above 0 = okay. Above 50 = excellent. Survey quarterly and track trend.

sections.title: Preventing Churn
items: Identify at-risk: Monitor usage patterns (declining engagement = risk)
Intervene early: Reach out before they decide to leave
Win-back campaigns: Special offers for churned customers
Exit interviews: Ask why they're leaving, learn
Address feedback: Fix common complaints
Annual plans: Lock in commitment with discount
Community: Belonging keeps people engaged

quiz.question: How much more expensive is acquiring vs. retaining?
options: 5x more expensive to acquire than retain
quiz.explanation: 5x more expensive to acquire new customer than retain existing one. Plus retained customers buy more over time. Fix retention before scaling acquisition.

quiz.question: What's the 'aha moment'?
quiz.explanation: Aha moment: when customer experiences core value. Correlates with retention. Goal: get new users to aha moment in first session if possible.

sections.content: Profitable businesses fail from cash flow problems. Revenue isn't profit. Profit isn't cash. You can be profitable on paper and out of cash in bank. Understanding basics of financial management isn't optional—it's survival skill. You don't need to be accountant, but you need to understand: revenue, expenses, profit, cash flow, runway.

sections.title: Key Financial Concepts
items: Revenue: Money coming in from sales
Cost of Goods Sold (COGS): Direct costs to deliver product/service
Gross Profit: Revenue - COGS
Operating Expenses: Rent, salaries, marketing, software, etc.
Net Profit: Gross Profit - Operating Expenses
Cash Flow: Actual money in and out of bank
Runway: Months until money runs out

sections.content: The unit economics: Understand profitability per customer. CAC (Customer Acquisition Cost) vs. LTV (Lifetime Value). If CAC = $100 and LTV = $300, you make $200 per customer. Scale this. If CAC > LTV, every customer loses money. Fix before scaling or you'll just lose money faster.

sections.title: Essential Metrics
items: Monthly Recurring Revenue (MRR): Predictable monthly revenue
Burn rate: How much cash you spend monthly
Runway: Months of cash left at current burn rate
Gross margin: (Revenue - COGS) / Revenue
CAC payback period: Months to recover customer acquisition cost
LTV:CAC ratio: Should be 3:1 or better
Cash conversion cycle: Time from spending to collecting

sections.title: Managing Cash Flow
items: Invoice promptly: Send invoices immediately
Payment terms: Net 15 or prepayment when possible
Follow up: Chase late payments
Reserve: 3-6 months expenses in bank
Forecast: Project cash flow 3-6 months ahead
Delay expenses: Pay on last day terms allow
Line of credit: Safety net for gaps

sections.content: The profit-first method: When revenue comes in, immediately allocate percentages to different accounts: Profit (5-10%), Owner's Pay (40-50%), Taxes (15%), Operating Expenses (remainder). This ensures you pay yourself and save profit before expenses consume everything.

sections.title: Financial Planning
items: Budget: Plan expenses and revenue monthly
Track: Record all transactions (accounting software)
Review: Check financials weekly
Benchmark: Compare to industry standards
Forecast: Project future based on trends
Scenarios: Model best, expected, worst case
Professional help: Accountant once revenue $100K+

quiz.question: What's the difference between profit and cash flow?
options: Profit is on paper (revenue - expenses); cash flow is actual money in/out of bank
Cash flow is for large companies only
quiz.explanation: Profit = revenue - expenses on paper. Cash flow = actual money in/out of bank. Can be profitable but out of cash. Both matter for survival.

quiz.question: What should LTV:CAC ratio be?
quiz.explanation: LTV:CAC should be 3:1 or better. Customer lifetime value should be at least 3x acquisition cost. Below this, unit economics don't work.
